comments.commentBody: Unfortunately, Gary Johnson was ignorant of the fact that Aleppo was the fifth Marx Brother.

You, sir, are talking through your hat.

Tao Te Ching

Written by Lao-tzu
From a translation by S. Mitchell

Last updated 20 July 1995
1

The tao that can be told
is not the eternal Tao
The name that can be named
is not the eternal Name.

The unnamable is the eternally real.
Naming is the origin
of all particular things.

Free from desire, you realize the mystery.
Caught in desire, you see only the manifestations.

Yet mystery and manifestations
arise from the same source.
This source is called darkness.

Darkness within darkness.
The gateway to all understanding.

Dr. Bardack notes she examined Mrs. Clinton today. She notes the diagnosis was made on Friday, but doesn't say that she examined her on Friday. She says 'she was put on antibiotics', OK, but when?

Being 'given a diagnosis of pneumonia' is something most doctors do in person, after x-rays and blood tests and a thorough exam. Nobody says if that happened or not, and 25 reporters follow her around every day. How hard would it be, if she saw the doctor on Friday, to say so?
Russian T is not "tyuh", it's Russian "uh" that's pronounced "yuh".

.
No justice? The Jets lost by one point. Their kicker missed a point-after and a FG. The opposing kicker used to be the Jets' kicker.

I have no idea why this guy is in silhouette. But on Sunday we had EIDER and the quote in the Avatar intro was heard in the same year as this guy gave us sons of Elder.
Could also be Montague, which would use one of the ending words that is needed for the foreign cities!  And neither Montague (Massachusetts) nor Montpelier is that well known.
Surly you jest. Montpelier is a capital city!

Month Elder is Montpelier--one of the cleverest of the pairings.

But I'm having problems with some of the foreign cities!

For what it's worth, a change over to a Trump Administration would not, in and of itself, be an immediate "cure" to more than fifty years of Democratic rule in our blighted and neglected inner cities...inhabited mostly by African American.  It will take a gradual and cooperative change in attitude in both government AND those who live in those areas.  But by its mere occurrence, a change over to Trump would be a gigantic step in he right direction.

(1) Genuine access to Charter Schools, i.e., CHOICE in education; (2) Dynamic, business-oriented "Enterprise Zones" placed in the heart of our nation's poverty-stricken & crime-ridden inner-cities; (3) A "hand up"...which ANYONE can accept with dignity...rather than the usual and  perpetual "hand-out" from Democrats over the last 50 years;  (4) DIGNITY & PRIDE over resentment & bitterness, and (5) PERONAL ACHIEVEMENT over the perpetuation of anger, victimization and dependency. 

You know what the alternative is...just more of the same.

I don't care a whit about the NFL. I PLAY tennis; I've never PLAYED football. Although I am 68 years old, I can still play tennis, and I will until I can no longer. I have played in national senior tournaments at my level, and I love the game. I would no sooner not watch the US Open finals--for men or women--than I would not put my shoes on in the morning. I had hoped that Serena would have been in the final, but I have to say that Kerber and Plishkova gave us an amazing match--6-4, 4-6, 6-4--one break in each set. Exciting stuff. Football just doesn't do it. (And none of the players came out with a concussion--my son got five of them playing football in high school!)

Totally agree.   Novak once again developing an ailment to give himself a break.   Back in the day Andy Roddick called it bird flu.    To be fair, he's been almost an unbeatable player for years now, but seemed not to  be in top form for this tournament.   Nonetheless, the medical breaks did not serve him well.   Stan has been in the shadow of Fed for years.    Now, at the age of 31, he is coming into his own.   I'm happy for Stan.  Three majors - finally.  Who would 'a thunk it?

Great to see Kerber and Stan the Man triumphant.
Tennis finally holds interest again to those of us tired of "the usual suspects."
Stan Wawrinka, the underestimated favorite all the time to win a grand slam. Why? Stan always the unsung hero. I don't think he can Wimbledon now but I wish he does.

Nah. The Stanimal is a different beast than before 3 years ago. He hasn't lost a tournament final since 2013 and has a kind of mental toughness to go alongside his physical refusal to give in that is definitely new as of 2014. He definitely has benefited from the decline of Nadal and Federer, but there's no way you beat Nadal and Djokovic in major finals without insane mental and physical toughness.

"The GOAT tennis club requires 10 slams for admission."
___________________
Really? Who decided that was a "rule?" You?

If winning 3 majors qualify a player for claim
to GOAT, the list will be long. In my opinion you
have to win 12 or more. This shows consistency,
maintaining fitness level and dedication.
Wawrinka is too inconsistent to be considered
a great player. Sometime he makes shots that
hit the lines or close and at other times he is
over the lines. His type of game , hitting the
lines or corners make it difficult to be consistent.
That is why he loses more often than wins.

Stan was 28, not 30, when he won his first major. And his delay ascending to the top was more to do with the Big Three. Andy and Stan are the second two, tied with three Grand Slams apiece. The GOAT tennis club requires 10  slams for admission.

Stan's brand of tennis is a pleasure to watch.  Clearly tough as nails, but he has the human traits that make him easy to root for.  I hope he continues to play at this level for several more years.  Professional tennis would be less enjoyable without him.

Another old timer thoroughly agrees Joker's injury time outs are best understood as intended to interrupt Stanimal's momentum. A form of cheating. I vote to take a giant step into the past when the rule was "play shall be continuous". If you couldn't continue, you defaulted.

Calm down! Tennis is not like the other sports you mention....stopping play to treat injuries is a way to enable the player to return to the match, for the match to have a proper outcome and for the spectators to get their time and money's worth. There are no substitutes or even other teammates to carry the load as in other sports you mention and much of the world sees fighting sports as cruel and unwatchable...boxing is not a model for other sports to follow. And tennis rules do not allow players to seek treatment for being tired as you think they do.

Before you compare tennis to all these other sports, think about how you would feel if you had traveled hundreds or thousands of miles and spent hundreds or thousands of dollars for seat at a tournament in Spain or America or England or Italy....and a set or so into the match, the referee ends the match as you want, because the referee perceives the player is a malingerer.

Its a well-recognized aspect of tennis that players must maintain the highest standards of their own mental and physical fitness and be able to withstand the antics of their opponents, the noise and comments from spectators and questionable calls by officials.....plus wind and heat. You have to stay fully "in the zone" for the entire match even if all those things are conspiring against you....apparently Stan was able to do that.

Djokovic appeared to have cramps, not problems with his feet. When the camera zoomed in on his feet, nary a drop of blood to be seen. It is difficult to believe he had torn toenails that were bleeding, All the more reason Wawrinka is the true champion.

once brian early, tournament referee, enters the court, it's like the arrival of the evil angel, something bad will happen to the match, look it up...he may be the one partick mcE has in mind when he called the enforcement of rules "gutless."

Stan won 6-7, 6-4,7-5, 3-1. The umpire failed to reward the match to Stan after Novak could no longer play. The fans new the match was over and yet Novak was allowed to rest for a long time to get his strength back. This is wrong. When a player is beaten they must forfeit or the umpire must default the player who refuses to play. Marathon runners do not get to stop the clock when they are tired or injured. Basketball, baseball, and football players don't get to stop the game. Boxers are disqualified if they are too injured to continue. Tennis is no different. The ATP and the USTASHI need to fix this before the sport loses integrity. Those long rest breaks helped Novak get back into the match. Stan lost some momentum during those breaks. It wasn't right.

As a "senior" tennis player, I loved the women's final. A 6-4, 4-6, 6-4 score is amazing--one service break per set. I thought we were treated to extraordinary tennis, although I must say, in that first set, the commentators had Pliskova beaten by the fourth game! I found that they did that to many of the players--one might get down by a couple of games, and the commentators would dismiss the player, only to watch that player come back. (What WAS LZ Grandson's expertise in tennis, anyway?) Neither one of those women in that final lost, in my opinion; both were winners. Such exciting tennis. That's why I love it. That's why I continue to play it. Thanks so much to Kerber and Pliskova!

.
.
Oh, Deb -- about your blog title:

Missouri Rep. Todd Akin claimed expertise about human physiology, but neither the colon nor the semicolon was implicated. I think his expertise extended only to the workings of the human female's reproductive system. He knows how to shut down fertilization.

He sure was a stupid "EM DASH cker", if I may bowdlerize George Carlin. As such, he would have fit right in with some of our other esteemed Senators.

I hope there will be much more serious questioners.  From what I've been reading, that does not seem likely.  The TV personalities labeled "newscasters" should be slightly better informed and analytical than Lauer.  That's a pathetic standard.  I don't think they have any idea how to encourage a serious debate.  The superficial, time-constrained format won't help.

It's hard to imagine it getting any worse, this Trump saga. Still, there's a lot of archival material to be studied--that of father and offspring. Donald said, in expressing support for the Iraq war, that it was a pity that they hadn't done the job properly first time around. That is the classic Neo-con position, but I doubt DT is sophisticated enough to understand that. It's more likely that his view was that of the shoot-from-the-lip bully.

Actually, he'd probably be fine with living there as long as he was an 'insider' oligarch.  How he must long for a society where everyone 'gets' him and will just bow down to his incredible powers of personal persuasion.  Not.

@darcey
Thank you for illustrating so very clearly why Trump is enamored with Vladimir Putin, and what would happen to this country were he to be elected.
Hopefully someone out there is listening.

Donald is an idiot first to insult John McCain and now to praise Putin.

True, our own president is an embarrassment for all the damage he has done to our nation from dismantling and decimating the fighting ability of our armed forces to giving Iran billions of dollars to make a one sided nuclear deal which is going to blow up in our cities sooner than later.

Put is an enemy of ours. He kills journalists, sides with Assad in killing Kurds, Syrians and soon Americans.

I would rather see Trump win than Hillary and all her baggage and lies but someone has to restrain Trump and I hope its not the guy who shouted back at Bernies' protesters,. "Go back to Auschwitz" because there are too many anti-Jews flocking to Trump's corner.

@wolfe
You're in Chicago -- have you been to the South Side lately???
That's a hint of what's wrong with capitalism....

Trump also admires Saddam Hussein.  His leadership models speak volumes about who Trump really is and what kind of government he would strive for.  Trump rejects everything this country has fought and died for with every cell in his body.

@schmoe
And your point is??? Look. It's a well-known fact that this war was on the planning table well before there was any military intervention, and it is lasting longer than anyone cares to think about -- But sorry, that still doesn't make it "Hillary Clinton's war."
And yes. We know who's in NATO.
